p: It has been demonstrated that nitrogen deposition causes a decrease in species richness in the Swiss montane grasslands, with oligotrophic, and usually rare, species being particularly disfavored (Roth et al. 2013). Subalpine and alpine grasslands are likely more vulnerable to negative effects of N deposition, as they have shorter growing seasons and generally thinner and nutrient poorer soils (Bowman et al. 2012). However, increased N depositions may have different consequences between habitats: using a plant trait analysis, Maskell et al. ( 2010) showed that eutrophication and acidification occurred, both of which can be responsible for species loss. Indeed, in a moss‐dominated alpine heath of Northern Europe, N deposition seems to trigger a decline of plant diversity and of shrub, bryophyte and lichen covers, but an increase in the graminoid cover (Armitage et al. 2014).
